comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/people/state-records-nsw/] There is a photo in your collection titled 'Unidentified passenger liner berthed at Dalgety's Wharf, Millers Point (NSW)' which shows the same event. Though unidentified it does have the correct date of 8 May 1903. It may be of interest that the Medic, of the White Star Line, was involved in a controversial famous prank in 1900, perpetrated by Charles Lightoller, who later went on to be the most senior surviving officer of the ill-fated Titanic.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Well spotted pellethepoet.

Many of the architectural features of the wharf buildings are similar to those of workers' family cottages which were also built in Millers Point around this time after the bubonic plague induced demolitions. The cottages still exist today as  NSW state government owned public housing

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wonderful photo(s). Wonderful prank story. 8th May 1903 was a Friday. I thought this might have been at one of the new finger wharves in Walsh Bay, but no, Dalgety's and the White Star Line wharves were on the west side of Miller's Point. See this rather odd 1905 bird's eye interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-f115-sd&rgn=0.5...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Another view of the Medic at Dalgety's Wharf

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Good spot; with that first photo you included you can see the same three men standing near the ladder and the man sitting on a box on the other side of the ladder. So we can add 8 May 1903 to this image and "SS Medic at Millers Point" to the other (and also to the one just above). Thanks!

That was a prank story that back-fired, huh :D

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: It may be of interest that Dalgety's "old wharf" was on the other side of Millers Point, in Walsh Bay, just off Kent Street. See Plan D, Map of Resumption Area bounded by Lower Fort Street, Windmill Street, Kent Street North and Port Jackson (Within section 91 and Part of Section 90), 03 May 1900. And for all the Resumption maps - gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/index.php/galleries/maps-and-p...
